title: Start
body:
This is a test!!!

The test continues!

And here is the last line.

title: Example_Encounter
body: No birds yet.

title: Example_SmallTalk
body: Example Dialog

title: Day_Chat_01
body:
Greg: The guide says this area has a nice range of species.

Greg: What bird are you looking out for?

Greg: What about a Western Pipistrelle?

Judd: That's a bat.

Greg: Oh, right.

Judd: I just want some nice photos.

title: Day_Chat_02
body:
Greg: Oh look, a nest of baby birds!
Greg: I remember when my kids left the nest.
Greg: It feels empty, but I also have more time for hobbies.

Judd: I never had kids.
Judd: I wanted to, though.

Greg: Oh.

Judd: And baby birds are called hatchlings.

title: Day_Chat_03
body:
Greg: How long do you want to stay out here?

Greg: Before we take a break, not for the whole trip.

Judd: I dunno.

Greg: Five minutes? 
Greg: Five hours? 
Greg: Five days? 
Greg: Five years?

Judd: ...
Judd: If I were to guess, three more birds.

title: AW_Start
body:
An Acorn Woodpecker appeared! 

Look at that red cap!

title: Effect_Good
body: You did a thing and the bird is affected somehow!

title: Too_Agitated
body: Careful! If you keep taking photos without relaxing you'll scare the bird off!

title: Effect_Bad
body: Uh, ok, that bird is not looking happy.

title: AW_Battle_Exit_Day
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: Did you know that Acron Woodpeckers like to hoard acorns?

Judd: They'll peck out lots of little holes in a tree, and then stash an acorn in each hole.

Judd: It's like swiss cheese, but with filled with acorns.

Greg: I guess sometimes the acorn... doesn't fall far from the tree!

Judd: Wow.

title: AW_AG_GREAT
body: The woodpecker is calmly adjusting its stash of nuts.

title: AW_AG_OK
body: The woodpecker is pecking out a hole in the tree.

title: AW_AG_BAD
body: The woodpecker is squawking and flying around.

title: Bird_Fled
body: Judd: They fley away. Drat!

title: Battle_Exit
body: Nice Picture!

title: AW_Approach
body: Judd: I'm hearing some loud squawks in this direction.

title: Bird_Found
body: Info: Bird sighted!

title: BT_Start
body:
A flock of Bushtits appeared!

They're so fluffy!

title: BT_Approach
body: Judd: Sounds like there's a flock of songbirds in those bushes.

title: BT_Battle_Exit_Day
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: Bushtits like to hang upside down sometimes when looking for food.

Judd: They're difficult to attract to feeders, because they only eat insects.

Greg: If there's 30 in a bush, how much would one in the hand be worth?

Judd: ...

title: BT_AG_GREAT
body: The bushtits are resting in some shrubs.

title: BT_AG_OK
body: The bushtits are singing and flying around.

title: BT_AG_BAD
body: The bushtits are swarming up, angrily squeaking!

title: AK_Start
body: It's an American Kestrel!

title: AK_Approach
body: Judd: There's a tiny hawk flying around in the distance.

title: AK_Battle_Exit_Day
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: Kestrels like to eat grasshoppers, lizards, mice, and sparrows.

Judd: They'll hover in midair trying to zero in on prey, and then swoop in!

Judd: They like to build their nests high up, and the male and the female both help keep the eggs warm.

Greg: Do you think they ever try hawking their mice to the local owls?

Judd: ...

title: AK_AG_GREAT
body: The kestrel is resting on a fence post.

title: AK_AG_OK
body: The kestrel is flying around, looking for prey.

title: AK_AG_BAD
body: The kestrel is angrily diving at the ground!

title: Camera_NotEnoughShots
body: We should take a couple more shots to make sure we get a good one.

title: Run_Away_Option
body: Info: Look for a different bird? You might not see this one again!

title: Run_Away
body: Judd: Let's go look for other birds.

title: AG_OK
body: Your hands are getting a little jittery.

title: AG_BAD
body: Your poor breathing is spooking them!

title: AG_GREAT
body: You feel perfectly calm.

title: AG_LEAVE
body: The bird flew away! You spooked them too much!

title: Day_Chat_04
body:
Greg: These birds love to sing, don't they?
Greg: I wonder what they're singing about.

Judd: Mating.

Greg: Well, maybe there's other songs too.

Judd: No. It's only mating.
Judd: Mating and food.

title: Day_Chat_05
body:
Greg: I hope this last bird has a neat looking beak.
Greg: That's my favorite feature, the beak.

Judd: Yeah, maybe.
Judd: I prefer the plumage, though.

title: End_Of_Day
body:
Judd: Let's head back. I need a rest.

Judd: My hands are swelling too much.

Greg: Okay.

Judd: Knees are going too.

Greg: Okay.

Judd: Shoes don't fit like they used to.

Greg: ...

Judd: Used to be able to go out all day, not so much anymore.

title: Intermission_01
body:
Greg: Let's take a load off.

Judd: ...

Greg: Hey, why'd you bring that bag of seed?

Judd: I wanted some photos of them eating.

Greg: We're not supposed to feed the animals here.

Greg: It's against the park rules!

Judd: ...

Judd: Oh... this bag is mostly catfood.

Judd: Nevermind.

Judd: I don't even remember when I had my last cat.

Greg: Have a good night.

<<await fade cabin-day>>

Clock: 4:00 AM

<<play alarm>>

Clock: ALARM

Judd: Rise and shine.

Greg: Ugghhhhh

Greg: I'll never get used to this.

Judd: Yeah, well, we're up. Let's go snap some pictures while it's dark out.

Judd: And then we can get breakfast.

...

Info: Hello, this is the videogame developer again. I hope you don't mind my intrusion.
Info: Are you have a good time birding? I really hope so.
Info: If you'd like to see some of these birds for yourself, try going to "feederwatch.org" in your web browser.
Info: They have lots of tips on how to attract birds in your area.
Info: Now, let's get back to the story.

title: Too_Calm
body: You are already as calm as can be.

title: WS_Approach
body:
Judd: Looks like there's something moving in the river.

Judd: Want to go on a snipe hunt?

title: WS_Start
body:
It's a Wilson's Snipe!

That beak is so long!

title: SJ_Start
body:
It's a Steller's Jay!

Wow! Such a bright color!

title: SJ_Approach
body: Judd: There's a hint of blue in the trees over there.

title: SJ_Battle_Exit_Day
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: Steller's Jays love to raid picnics. They're omnvimores, so they'll eat anything you can throw at them.

Judd: They hog all the food at feeders, carrying it away to store for the winter.

Greg: Wow, this Jay doesn't sound very stellar at all!

Judd: ... that's actually a very common mispelling
Judd: People think it's stellar as in cool instead of steller as in Georg Steller, who discovered it.

Greg: Sounds like some people aren't steller spellers!

Judd: Oh my Lord.

title: WS_Battle_Exit_Day
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: When I was young at summer camp, some kids convinced me to go on a snipe hunt.
Judd: I had to stand in a marsh at midnight, holding a bag. There were no snipes.
Judd: I didn't think Snipes were real for the longest time, until I bought my first birding book.

Greg: You didn't catch a snipe, but at least you didn't catch a cold!
Judd: I did, actually.

title: Night_Chat_01
body:
Greg: The sun isn't even up yet, are there really going to be birds out?

Judd: Sure, there's owls and other nocturnal birds.
Judd: A lot of birds get up before sunrise as well.

Greg: I suppose.
Greg: How do you get up this early every day?

Judd: I haven't slept well since Margret got sick.
Judd: Eventually I stopped trying.
Judd: But atleast there were birds when I gave up.

Greg: ...

title: Night_Chat_02
body:
Greg: Where do you want to eat after this?

Greg: We could go to one of the restaurants in the park when they open...

Judd: They're probably too expensive.

Greg: Well, it's going to be a drive to go anyplace else.

Judd: Yeah, I know. We can go to the restaurant near our cabin. They do breakfast at 7.

Greg: Sounds good. I'll need more coffee...

title: Night_Chat_03
body:
Greg: How do you spot any of these birds? It's too dark out.

Judd: You just need to know what to look for. And what to listen for.
Judd: I've been birding for 23 years.
Judd: They can't hide from me, even if my senses are slowly getting worse...

title: Night_Chat_04
body:
Greg: I'm going to need a coffee and a break soon.

Judd: Yeah, ok. But two more birds first.
Judd: I can hear a couple more I want to check out.

Greg: Sigh... alright.

title: Night_Chat_05
body:
Judd: Alright, one more bird and we can get out of here.
Judd: There's some eggs and toast with my name on them.
Greg: Bird eggs.
Judd: Chickens are birds, yes.

title: Rain_Chat_01
body:
Judd: This rain... it makes my sinuses ache.

Greg: Will you be able to handle it?
Greg: These birds won't watch themselves!

Judd: Aches and pains are the only thing that keep me company.
Judd: That and the birds.

title: Rain_Chat_03
body:
Greg: Some of these bird nests look quite colorful!

Judd: They're using trash for nesting.
Judd: Newspaper, magazines, straws, anything that can keep together and retain heat.

Greg: Oh, that's a shame.

Judd: At least they have a family.

title: Rain_Chat_02
body:
Judd: That's all the birds I wanted to see. Ready to go?

Greg: We just got back out here!
Greg: Let's stick around a bit longer.

Judd: Fine.

title: Rain_Chat_04
body:
Greg: There's so many different birds out here!
Greg: Way more than what I see at my feeder.

Judd: You just don't know how to attract them.
Judd: You need the right food, the right feeder and the right places for them to nest.
Judd: You can't just buy a bag of seed from Flowerland and expect results. You'll just get finches.

Greg: I haven't given bird feeding that much thought!

title: Rain_Chat_05
body:
Judd: Let's head back after this one.

Greg: Sure. It's been a long day.

title: Intermission_02
body:
Judd: How was your coffee?

Greg: Pretty good. I think I'm perking up!

Judd: Ok.

Greg: Weather says it's going to rain for the rest of today.
Greg: Are we still going birding after we eat?

Judd: Of course.
Judd: Some birds prefer the rain. My camera is waterproof too.

Greg: Alright.
Greg: Well, I hope none of those birds were planning on a parade!

Judd: ... 
Judd: I see that coffee is working...

title: EG_Approach
body: Judd: There's a flock of yellow birds in those tree tops.

title: EG_Start
body:
It's flock of Evening Grosbeaks!

Look at those eyebrows!

title: EG_Battle_Exit_Night
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: I'm surprised we managed to find some Evening Grosbeaks.
Judd: Their migration patterns are very unpredictable, so you never know if they're around this season.
Judd: I'm happy I managed to get some pictures.

Greg: Do you think they clean their beaks often?

Judd: Probably as much as any other bird while bathing.

Greg: That's good, I thought they might have gross beaks!

Judd: ...

Judd: ...

Judd: ...

title: CM_Approach
body: Judd: I see something floating along on the river.

title: CM_Start
body:
It's a Common Merganser!

It looks happy to be surrounded by water.

title: CM_Battle_Exit_Rain
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: The Common Merganser has serrated edges on its bill to help with gripping fish. Some call this a "sawbill".
Judd: They'll develop a pink tinge if they eat enough shellfish, like flamingos.
Judd: Common Merganser highly prefer water over land. They're bad at running on solid ground.

Greg: One time a Common Merganser flew near my restaurant table when I was eating outside.

Judd: Really? People must have been feeding them a lot to get that tame.

Greg: Yeah, but once he saw the bill he flew off! What a jerk!

Judd: ...

title: JD_Approach
body: Judd: There are dark birds hopping around on the ground over there.

title: JD_Start
body:
It's Dark-eyed Junco!

Lookin stylish, even if it's only black, white, and brown!

title: JD_Battle_Exit_Night
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: The Dark-eyed Junco is one of most common feeder birds across North America.
Judd: They like all kinds of bird feed. Sunflower seeds, cracked corn, millet, oats, even peanuts.
Judd: They like to eat off the ground, or feeders with a platform they can stand on.

Greg: Neat!

Judd: ...

Judd: No pun?

Greg: Nope! I've got nothing!

Judd: ...

Judd: I'm a little disappointed.

title: NS_Approach
body: Greg: I hear some hoots coming from that conifer.

title: NS_Start
body:
It's a Northern Saw-whet Owl!

What a cute face!

title: NS_Battle_Exit_Night
body:
Greg: Nice photo!

Judd: The Northern Saw-whet Owl has a very good sense of hearing.
Judd: In fact, they hunt for mice purely through the sounds their prey make.
Judd: They're so small, you could fit them in a coffee can.

Greg: Hopefully that can would clean and dry.

Judd: Well, of course, some people use it as a method of weighing them.

Greg: I never saw a wet owl, but I wouldn't want that to be the first time!

Judd: ...

title: Intermission_03
body:
Judd: Ready to leave?

Greg: Huh? Already?

Judd: I've seen all the birds I wanted too.

Greg: We're not getting kicked out of our cabin until tomorrow morning!

Greg: Don't you want to see more of the park? It took us six hours to drive here!

Judd: Nope, I'm done.
Judd: I came, I saw, I photographed.
Judd: I need to check on Marget, anyways.

Greg: ...

Greg: Alright, if you're that sure, we can leave.
Greg: Same time next year?

Judd: Sure.

Info: FIN

Info: ...

<<await fade cabin-day>>

Info: ...

Info: Hello again, it's me. The developer of this computer game.
Info: I hope you had a good time birding out there with our two friends.
Info: This story might be over, but you can still have your own adventures with birds!
Info: Check out the description on this game's web page for ways to check out birds for yourself!
Info: Thanks for playing!



<<show ending-image>>

title: Encounter_Tutorial
body:
Info: Hello, I am this computer game's developer with some helpful tips to get you through the game.
Info: Our goal here is to get a good photo of that bird over there.
Info: If you use your camera, you can snap some photos of it. I think we need ten photos before we'll get a good one.
Info: When you're ready to start, move your mouse cursor over the camera icon and perform a click action on the mouse.
Info: This computer game is operated only by moving the mouse and clicking, so don't worry about any other keyboard buttons!

title: Post_Camera_Tutorial
body:
Info: Taking photos can get stressful! If you get too stressed then your hands will be too shakey to operate the camera.
Info: We may need to do some breathing exercises to calm down when that happens.
Info: To do that, perform a click on the "breathing" menu option.
Info: Right now you're only a little stressed out, so you can take another set of pictures first, if you'd like.
Info: ...
Info: Oh! And before I forget, I'll explain the other two menu options.
Info: The book option will give you additional information about the bird, including tips on how to get photos.
Info: The walk-away menu option will skip to the next bird, if you don't feel like taking a picture of this bird!
Info: Ok. That's all the options. Let's get back to it!

title: Camera_Tutorial
body:
Info: It is me, the game's developer again. Sorry to be back so soon!
Info: To snap a picture of a bird, hover your cursor over the bird and click the mouse button to snap a photo.
Info: As long as the bird is within your camera's field of view, you'll be able take the picture.
Info: Make sure the bird isn't touching the edges! We don't want them partially out of frame!

title: Breathing_Tutorial
body:
Info: Ready to chill out?
Info: Start by depressing the mouse button. This will make your blue "breath box" move to the right.
Info: When the "breath box" reaches green zone on the right, release the mouse button.
Info: This will make the breath box start moving back to the left.
Info: Depress the mouse button when it reaches the green zone on the left, then rinse and repeat!
Info: You'll take 3 exhales and 3 inhales before being ranked.
Info: This first time though, take as many as you like! Once you take 6 OK inhales or exhales you can move on.

title: Day_Chat_Intro
body:
Greg: Well, here we are. Yosemete park.

Greg: What a drive.

Judd: ...

Greg: Is your camera ready?

Judd: Yeah.

Greg: Got your birding book?

Judd: Yeah.

Greg: Your best jacket?

Greg: Your lucky socks?

Greg: Your favorite hat?

Judd: (Ugh)

Judd: Let's go snap some bird photos.

title: AW_Book
body:
Book: Acorn Woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus).
Book: Acorn Woodpeckers live in large groups and hoard acorns.
Book: They're pretty easy to find, and are tolerant of humans.
Book: They live in forests on slopes and mountains.
Book: They'll fly from tree to tree while you take pictures. Try predicting which tree they're flying to!

title: BT_Book
body:
Book: American Bushtit (Psaltriparus minimus)
Book: Bushtits are tiny, kinglet-sized birds.
Book: They typically fly around bushes in large flocks, looking for insects to eat.
Book: Look around in bushes to get a picture. The Bushtit will fly away when you snap a picture, but there should be plenty more!

title: AK_Book
body:
Book: American Kestrel (Falco sparverius)
Book: The Kestrel is the smallest, most common North American falcon.
Book: They're usually seen perched high up on fence posts and telephone poles.
Book: They catch their prey by swooping down and scooping up mice.
Book: If you can follow their trajectory, you'll get lots of photos!

title: WS_Book
body:
Book: Wilson's Snipe (Gallinago delicata)
Book: The Wilson's Snipe is a pudgy shorebird with short stocky legs and a bill several times longer than its head.
Book: Snipes love the mud, because they eat by probing the mud with their long bill for worms!
Book: Snipes fly in a zigzag pattern, so when you're taking a picture, be ready for some erratic movement!

title: SJ_Book
body:
Book: Steller's Jay (Cyanocitta stelleri)
Book: The Steller's Jay is a large songbird with a prominent triangular crest. It was named after Georg Wilhelm Steller.
Book: Steller's Jays are bold and curious. They like hop around on the ground, looking for food.
Book: Try waiting until they fly down to the ground, and then snap lots of photos until they fly away!

title: EG_Book
body:
Book: Evening Grosbeak (Coccothraustes vespertinus)
Book: Evening Grosbeaks are large, yellow finches. They are also quite social, appearing in flocks.
Book: Grosbeaks like to fly around trees, looking for bugs, seeds, and berries.
Book: They move very eratically, so try your best to track them in the trees when taking a picture!

title: NS_Book
body:
Book: Northern Saw-whet Owl (Aegolius acadicus)
Book: The Northern Saw-whet is the smallest owl in North America. It has a cat-like face and big, bright yellow eyes.
Book: Saw-whets like to roost in dense conifers during the day and hunt at night. 
Book: If you hear other birds kicking up a fuss, it might be because they found a Saw-whet!
Book: If you can track the owl in the trees, you'll be able to get plenty of pictures!

title: JD_Book
body:
Book: Dark-eyed Junco (Junco hyemalis)
Book: The Dark-eyed Junco is the most well known species of junco. It lives all across North America.
Book: They like to hop around on the ground looking for seeds.
Book: You can easily find Juncos by walking around open, wooded areas and watching the ground.
Book: If you can track them as they hop around, taking a picture will be a snap!

title: CM_Book
body:
Book: Common Merganser (Mergus merganser)
Book: The Common Merganser is a large duck that floats along rivers and lakes.
Book: This duck eats dish as makes nests in hollow trees.
Book: If you can keep track of it as it floats down the river, you'll get lots of photos.

title: End_Of_Night
body:
Greg: You ready for some breakfast?

Judd: Yeah. Let's go eat.
Judd: We can review the pictures we took too.

Greg: Always business with you, isn't it?

title: End_Of_Rain
body:
Judd: Let's go. I need a shower and some dry clothes.

Greg: But we've been showering all day!

Judd: Certainly not a hot shower.

Greg: Hoho, true.
Greg: I suppose my socks are getting a bit damp!

Judd: Well, mine are soaked.

title: AW_Battle_Exit_Night
body:
Greg: What a picture!

Judd: Acorn Woodpeckers have the potential of being pests.
Judd: They store acorns in anything wooden. Fence posts, telephone poles, even houses!
Judd: You can add netting to the side of your house, or set up predator sculptures to scare them off.

Greg: What about ghosts? Are they scared of ghosts?

Judd: No.
Judd: But if that fails, you can always trap them and release them somewhere else.

Greg: I think I'm on the fence for what approach to take!

Judd: ...

title: AK_Battle_Exit_Rain
body:
Greg: Another great photo!

Judd: Kestrels nest in cavities. They can't dig out their own, so a male searches for sutable nesting areas.
Judd: They look in holes dug out by woodpeckers, rock crevices, and man-made nooks.
Judd: One he finds some candidates, he shows them to the female, who makes the final decision.

Greg: Wow, that sounds similar to humans!
Greg: Birds love to or-kestr-ate everything!

Judd: ... birds as in women?

Greg: Yeah that's idea.

title: WS_Battle_Exit_Rain
body:
Judd: The word "sniper" originated in 1770 from British soldiers in India, who hunted snipes as game.
Judd: Snipes fly in a really erratic way, so they're difficult shooting targets.

Greg: I'd much rather shoot photos than shoot birds!

Judd: Agreed.

title: SJ_Battle_Exit_Night
body:
Judd: Steller's Jays love to rob eggs from nests. 
Judd: They'll also attack smaller birds, like Dark-Eyed Juncos.
Judd: Despite this, they are quite beautiful to look at.

Greg: I suppose crooks can be deceiving!

Judd: ...

title: JD_Battle_Exit_Rain
body:
Judd: Dark-Eyed Juncos like to build their nests on the ground, rarely on branches or ledges.
Judd: They weave together twigs, grass, and pine needles to make the nest.
Judd: Their eggs are off-white, with brown speckles.

Greg: I'll bet their nest building skills are egg-ceptional!

Judd: ... yeah

title: NS_Battle_Exit_Rain
body:
Judd: Female Saw-whet Owls keep their nest very clean.
Judd: But, once she leaves her hatchlings behind, they make quite a mess.
Judd: By the time all the kids leave, the nest is full of feces, pellets, and parts of rotting prey.

Greg: Sounds like my family!
Greg: Really should have toilet-trained those boys...

Judd: ... what?
